frameDefinitions: In this frame, an Agent changes the temperature of an Item.
The frame represents the result state of the Entity after event represented by the Undergo_change frame.

This frame deals with a Speaker communicating a reply or response, a Message, to some prior communication or action, the Trigger.  '' 'The landlord has not yet replied in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.
A Communicator publically communicates some difficult-to-express Content which they (or a social group of which they are a member) have had for some time.
A person (Speaker) expresses a Message or mental content, broadly understood, in a particular Manner.

A Communicator speaks to an Addressee in such a way that the Addressee understands and fully appreciates the truth and/or relevance of the Message.   ' Marred by overblown writing , this first novel by Wilbur Smith 's wife effectively conveys some of South Africa 's problems .
frameExamples: Margaret Anne <t>chilled</t> the salad to 30 degrees.
The landlord has not yet <t>replied</t> in writing to the tenant objecting the proposed alterations.DNI
Those grievances can be <t>aired</t> during Board meetings. CNI
Marred by overblown writing , this first novel by Wilbur Smith 's wife effectively <t>conveys</t> some of South Africa 's problems .INI
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the intentional act which changes the temperature of the <fen>Item</fen>.
The <fen>Item</fen> undergoes the temperature change.
An animate or inanimate entity, a force, or event that changes the temperature. Volitionality is not a necessary characteristic of <fen>Cause</fen>s.
The <fen>Hot_Cold_source</fen> is the source of the heat or coolness.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when  the <fen>Agent</fen> changes the temperature of the <fen>Item</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where  the <fen>Agent</fen> changes the temperature of the <fen>Item</fen>.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> is the sentient entity that communicates the reply or response. It is expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of a <t>Target</t> verb or as the Genitive modifier of a <t>Target</t> noun:
This is the person to whom the response is communicated.  When expressed, this role occurs as the direct object of a <t>Target</t> verb, or in a prepositional phrase introduced by 'to':
The <fen>Message</fen> is the role that identifies the content of what the <fen>Speaker</fen> is communicating to the <fen>Addressee</fen>. It can be expressed as a direct quote or a clause.
<fen>Topic</fen> occurs quite rarely in this frame and usually only as a PP Complement of a noun <t>Target</t>:
The <fen>Trigger</fen> is the prior communication or action to which a response is given. It can occur as an NP Object or a PP Complement.
The time interval during which the <fen>Speaker</fen> makes their verbal response.
The location in which the <fen>Speaker</fen>  makes a verbal response.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> is the person who expresses the <fen>Content</fen> (whether spoken or written).
The attitude or feeling that the <fen>Communicator</fen> had not previously expressed.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the observable action or product of the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Content</fen> is communicated.
The role specifies the place where the communication takes place.
<fen>Speaker</fen>, the person who encodes the <fen>Message</fen>, occurs as the External Argument of all the verbs:
The <fen>Message</fen> is almost invariably expressed in an NP Object. (The only exceptions occur with the verb <t>express</t>, which is occasionally used with that-clause complements.)

For most of the words in this frame, some expression of <fen>Manner</fen> or <fen>Medium</fen> is obligatory. As in other frames, <fen>Manner</fen> expressions characterize the action (in this case, the speech act performed by the <fen>Speaker</fen>). However, a wide range of <fen>Manner</fen> expressions occurs in this frame, including the following types:
<fen>Medium</fen> expresses the <fen>Medium</fen> of communication, such as the language used or the specific type of text in which the <fen>Message</fen> occurs:
The person who uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to another person.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> receives a <fen>Message</fen> from the <fen>Communicator</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> A proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Ryan</fex> reheated the pasta in the microwave.
Ryan reheated <fex>the pasta</fex> in the microwave.
<fex>The sun</fex> warmed the house.
We chilled the drinks <fex>on ice</fex>.
<fex>Sue</fex> responded to the objection convincingly.
Sue answered <fex>Bob</fex> immediately.
<fex>'I can't help you,'</fex> Sue answered.
My boss still hasn't given me an answer <fex>about a promotion</fex>.
Sue answered <fex>the question</fex>.
A reminder letter was sent to all nonrespondents who had not replied <fex>after 28 days</fex>.
This was how Tamil Nadu Chief Minister Jayalalithaa responded <fex>in the Assembly</fex> on November 5, 2003.
<fex>Reagan</fex> gave voice to the innate patriotism of the American people.
Members aired <fex>their grievances</fex> and resented the way higher education was being dealt with.
I do not especially espouse the ideas articulated by Diana Plesa <fex>in her article</fex>.
Sometimes, children may <fex>later</fex> put into words a memory from early life, but not customarily.
John Ryan voiced concerns <fex>in Parliament</fex> about the suggestion that somehow the inquiry was not independent.
<fex>The teacher</fex> phrased the question carefully.
The Prime Minister expressed <fex>her sympathy for the victims</fex>.
True Manner: You should phrase it <fex>carefully</fex>.
Kim formulated her objections <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>Nobody</fex> seems to be able to get the idea through to her that she needs a job!!!!

According to Masztalics, a good teacher uses experiments to get the point across
<fex>to the class</fex>.
He tried to get through to his wife <fex>that the debt he's taken on buying stocks poses no risk</fex>.
<fex>The article</fex> conveys Mr. Handley's disrespect for those who disagree with him.
Greenspan got his point across <fex>yesterday</fex> that a measured pace of rate hikes is still the plan.
